'and' when it joins 2 imperatives with no shared objects; temporal ordering assumed;
synonym is ‘and_then’ or just ‘then’

Turn left now and turn right at the corner.
Turn right after the restaurant and then immediately turn left. 
Turn right then go left at the corner.
NEED SPECIAL ENTRY WHEN FIRST VERB IS
NEED SPECIAL ENTRY WHEN FIRST VERB IS CROSS
a street corner, corner of a room, etc.
Stanford thinks the imperative form is a noun
YOUR DESTINATION IS ON THE LEFT.
YOUR DESTINATION IS ON THE RIGHT.
phrasal: ‘left + PP’ meaning ‘turn left’ at the place indicated by PP
Note the checking condition – there cannot be a verb in this structure, otherwise it can mean ‘exactly + PP’ (e.g., Turn right right at the intersection’)
phrasal: ‘slight left + PP’ meaning ‘turn slight left’ at the place indicated by PP
Note the checking condition – there cannot be a verb in this structure, otherwise it can mean ‘exactly + PP’ (e.g., Turn right right at the intersection’)

Used when  modified by an adjective, like 'second left'.  Then Stanford thinks it's a noun.
              Note that the STREET REFSEM comes first, so that any modifiers like 'second' will get applied to it.

phrasal: ‘make a right turn’; imperative verb and DO “right turn”; I assume that PPs and adverbs can be compositionally added to this structure
phrasal: ‘make a left at the corner'
(GO TRAVEL DRIVE) NORTH ON BEACH STREET.
phrasal: ‘right + PP’ meaning ‘turn right’ at the place indicated by PP
Note the checking condition – there cannot be a verb in this structure, otherwise it can mean ‘exactly + PP’ (e.g., Turn right right at the intersection’)
phrasal: ‘slight right + PP’ meaning ‘turn slight right’ at the place indicated by PP
Note the checking condition – there cannot be a verb in this structure, otherwise it can mean ‘exactly + PP’ (e.g., Turn right right at the intersection’)

phrasal: ‘turn right’; imperative verb and adverb ‘right’; I assume that PPs and adverbs can be compositionally added to this structure

phrasal: ‘u-turn + PP’ meaning ‘turn left’ at the place indicated by PP
Note the checking condition – there cannot be a verb in this structure, otherwise it can mean ‘exactly + PP’ (e.g., Turn right right at the intersection’)
